entry.title: 🚀☁️ Migrating to SAP HANA Cloud: A Business Transformation Journey
entry.content:
About Me

Hare Krishna 🙏 I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

📝Introduction

In today’s fast-paced business environment, enterprises are under constant pressure to reduce costs 💰, accelerate innovation 🚀, and stay agile ⚡. Many organizations still run on-premise SAP HANA 🗄️ or ECC systems 🏢, which can limit scalability, slow analytics 📊, and increase IT overhead 🛠️.

Migrating to SAP HANA Cloud ☁️ offers a solution: a cloud-native, scalable, and intelligent platform 🤖 that not only modernizes your database but also unlocks new opportunities for business growth 📈, advanced analytics 📊, and AI-driven insights 🤖.

This blog explores the strategic advantages of moving to HANA Cloud, real-world scenarios, migration approaches, and how businesses can leverage this transformation for long-term success 🌟.

1. Why Businesses Should Care About Migration

SAP HANA on-premise has been the backbone of enterprise IT for over a decade. But today, companies face challenges like:

  • 💸Rising infrastructure and data center costs

  • 📉Difficulty scaling for seasonal or global demand

  • ⚡Pressure to innovate with real-time analytics and machine learning

SAP HANA Cloud is not just a database upgrade — it is a strategic enabler for business transformation:

  • ☁️Elastic scalability → pay only for what you use

  • 💰Lower TCO → no hardware refresh, no patching overhead

  • 🤖Built-in innovation → multi-model (graph, JSON, geospatial), ML integration, Datasphere

  • 🛡️ Cloud-grade resilience → HA, backups, encryption built in

👉For enterprises planning RISE with SAP, migration is often a key milestone. For GROW with SAP customers, HANA Cloud is already the default foundation.

2. A Real-World Story: Fashion Retailer Migrating During Peak Season

A large fashion retailer running ECC on HANA on-premise faced challenges during peak shopping seasons:

  • 🏬High traffic spikes during Black Friday, festive sales, and seasonal launches

  • 💾Hardware was over-provisioned to handle peak loads but under-utilized the rest of the year

  • 📊Analytics delays slowed decision-making for inventory replenishment, pricing, and promotions

By migrating to SAP HANA Cloud, the retailer was able to:

  • ☁️Scale compute resources elastically during high-demand weeks, then scale down during off-season

  • 📊Integrate sales, inventory, and supply chain data in SAP Datasphere for real-time visibility

  • 💰Reduce infrastructure costs by 25–30% while improving system performance

  • 🛒Optimize promotional planning and inventory allocation by leveraging faster analytics on HANA Cloud

👉Result: Smooth operations during peak shopping periods, lower costs, faster reporting, and improved customer satisfaction — all while creating a foundation for a future move to S/4HANA Cloud.

3.🛠️⚡ Migration Approach: Self-Service Tools for a Smooth Transition

Migrating to SAP HANA Cloud can be complex, but SAP provides self-service migration tools to simplify the process, reduce risk, and speed up implementation.

1️⃣Assessment & Planning

  • 🛠️ Review current HANA workloads, database size, and custom code.

  • 📝Decide whether to migrate using sidecar (DB only) or full migration.

  • 🔒Map compliance, security, and network requirements.

  • 📊Identify business processes to migrate first (e.g., analytics sandbox or critical ERP data).

👉Reference: SAP HANA Cloud Migration Guide

2️⃣Execution with SAP Self-Service Migration Tools

SAP HANA Cloud Migration Cockpit / DMO (Database Migration Option):

  • 🛠️ Self-service migration: Provides a guided, wizard-based process for migrating data from on-premise HANA or BTP HANA Service to HANA Cloud.

  • ⚡Supports multiple migration scenarios:

    • ECC on HANA → HANA Cloud (sidecar or full)

    • S/4HANA on-prem → HANA Cloud

    • SAP HANA Service on BTP CF → HANA Cloud

  • 🔄Automated delta replication: Keeps source and target databases in sync until cutover.

  • 🖥️ Validation & monitoring: Allows pre-checks, logs, and real-time monitoring of migration progress.

  • 🔗Seamless integration: Works with SAP tools like SLT/SDI, SUM/DMO, and SAP Cloud Transport.

Key Benefits:

  • Reduces manual steps and risk of errors.

  • Speeds up migration timeline.

  • Provides a self-service experience for IT teams, while still supporting SAP guidance and best practices.

👉Learning resource: SAP Learning Journey – Migrating SAP HANA to HANA Cloud

3️⃣Hands-On Simulation

  • 🖥️ Practice provisioning, configuring, and validating migration steps using SAP’s interactive simulation.

  • 👉Try it here: Enable Now Demo

4. Customer Scenarios: How Migration Helps Different Starting Points

🔹1. Customers on ECC on HANA (on-premise)

Current State:

  • 🗄️ Running legacy ECC (not yet S/4HANA) with an SAP HANA database on-premise

  • 💸Facing high infra + maintenance costs, limited innovation

How HANA Cloud Helps:

  • ☁️They can move their database layer first (sidecar or full migration) → reduce infra costs immediately

  • 🛠️ This becomes a stepping stone to RISE with SAP (moving ERP to S/4HANA Cloud later is easier if DB is already on HANA Cloud)

  • 📊Can use HANA Cloud for analytics scenarios while still keeping ECC running on-prem

Scenario Architecture:

[💻 Users/Apps]
      |
      v
+-------------------+        Initial Load          +---------------------+
| 🗄️ ECC (ABAP stack)|----------------------------->| ☁️ SAP HANA Cloud   |
+---------^---------+                              +----------^----------+
          |                                                 |
          |   Real-time Delta (SLT/SDI/DP Agent)            |
          +-----------------------------------------------> |
          |                                                 |
+---------+---------+                                       |
| 🗄️ SAP HANA (source)|<----- 🔗 VPN/Private Link/IPSec ---+
+-------------------+

👉Benefit: Lower TCO now, smoother path to S/4HANA in future

🔹2. Customers on S/4HANA On-Premise

Current State:

  • 🗄️ Already on S/4HANA, but hosted in on-premise data center

  • 💸Often invested in large HANA appliances sized for peak loads

How HANA Cloud Helps:

  • ☁️Lift & shift the database layer to HANA Cloud under RISE with SAP

  • ⚡Elastic scaling → no more overprovisioning

  • 📊Cloud-native features like multi-model DB and Datasphere integration unlock new business insights

  • 🛡️ Reduces IT overhead (patching, HA setup, backup) — handled by SAP

Scenario Architecture:

                +-------------------+
                | 🗄️ S/4HANA On-Prem |
                +---------^---------+
                          |  🛠️ DMO / Export-Import
                          |  + Optional continuous replication (SLT/SDI)
                          v
                 -------------------------- 🔗 Secure Network -------------------------
                          v
                +---------+---------+       +---------------------+      +-----------+
                | ☁️ SAP HANA Cloud  |<----->| 📊 SAP Datasphere   |<---->| 📊 SAC/BI |
                +---------^---------+       +----------^----------+      +-----^-----+
                          |                           |
                          | 🛠️ Destinations/XSUAA/CAP |
                          +---------------------------+

👉Benefit: Modernized infrastructure, cost savings, easier innovation, and alignment with SAP’s cloud-first roadmap

🔹3. Customers on SAP HANA Service on SAP BTP (Cloud Foundry)

Current State:

  • 🗄️ Using managed HANA instances in BTP CF, often for extension apps or analytics

  • ⚠️This service is being phased out in favor of HANA Cloud

How HANA Cloud Helps:

  • ☁️Migration ensures they’re on the strategic, supported database service

  • ⚡Feature parity and beyond (cloud-native scaling, multi-model)

  • 🛠️ Future-proof integration with BTP services like XSUAA, CAP, and Datasphere

Scenario Architecture:

 
+--------------------------------- BTP (CF) ---------------------------------+
|                                                                            |
|  +--------------------+           Data/Schema Move          +------------+ |
|  | 🗄️ HANA Service    |------------------------------------>| ☁️ HANA Cloud |
|  +---------^----------+                                     +-----^------+ |
|            | App Bindings (CAP/UI5/XSA)                      |             |
|            +----------------------------- Rebind/Retarget ---+             |
+----------------------------------------------------------------------------+

“Earlier SAP offered SAP HANA Service on BTP Cloud Foundry, but this has been fully retired and replaced by SAP HANA Cloud. Customers who were using HANA Service have already transitioned or are expected to migrate, since HANA Cloud is the only strategic database service supported by SAP.”

👉Benefit: Mandatory move for long-term support + added innovation opportunities

🔹4. Customers on Non-SAP Databases (Oracle, DB2, SQL Server) with ECC

Current State:

  • 🗄️ Legacy ECC on Oracle/DB2/SQL

  • 💸DB costs + performance issues

How HANA Cloud Helps:

  • ☁️Migrate directly to S/4HANA Cloud on HANA Cloud under RISE with SAP

  • ⚡Skip the intermediate step of on-prem HANA investment

  • 📊Immediately benefit from SAP’s innovation roadmap

Scenario Architecture:

[🗄️ Legacy ECC on Non-SAP DB] ---- Extract (ETL/LTMC) ---+
                                                        |
                                                        v
                                             +---------------------+
                                             | ☁️ S/4HANA Cloud    |
                                             +----------^----------+
                                                        |
                                             Standard Content & Mapping
                                                        |
                                                        v
                                             +---------------------+
                                             | ☁️ SAP HANA Cloud    |
                                             +---------------------+

👉Benefit: Leapfrog into cloud ERP without double investment

5. Migration Challenges & How to Overcome Them

While migrating to SAP HANA Cloud brings huge benefits, enterprises may face some challenges. Here’s what to watch for:

  • 🔄Data Volume & Delta Replication

    • Large datasets can slow migration.

    • Mitigation: Use SLT/SDI for incremental replication and pre-validate data mapping.

  • 🔐Security & Compliance

    • Sensitive business data needs encryption in transit and proper role mapping.

    • Mitigation: Configure VPN/Private Link, enforce identity/auth with XSUAA, and follow SAP security guidelines.

  • 🛠️ Custom ABAP Code & Extensions

    • Custom programs may have compatibility issues with HANA Cloud.

    • Mitigation: Test custom code in sandbox or trial HANA Cloud before cutover.

  • ⚡Application & Integration Dependencies

    • Connected apps or BI tools need retargeting.

    • Mitigation: Rebind or redirect connections to HANA Cloud and Datasphere endpoints.

  • ⏱️ Downtime & Cutover Planning

    • Minimizing business disruption is critical.

    • Mitigation: Plan cutover during off-peak periods, validate all delta loads, and communicate with stakeholders.

6. How This Fits with RISE & GROW with SAP

  • 🌟RISE with SAP → Migration is a natural step for existing ERP customers moving to S/4HANA Cloud

  • 🌱GROW with SAP → Net-new cloud ERP customers start directly on HANA Cloud and benefit from innovation immediately

7. Business Outcomes After Migration

  • 💰30–40% lower infrastructure costs

  • ⚡Faster innovation cycles with ML, JSON, graph, and Datasphere integration

  • 🌐Global reach through geo-replication

  • 🛡️ Operational resilience with automated HA and backups

8. Future Roadmap / Innovation After Migration

After migration, enterprises can unlock new business capabilities on HANA Cloud:

  • 🤖Machine Learning & Predictive Analytics

    • Forecast demand, optimize inventory, and personalize offers in retail.

  • 🌐Real-Time Data Integration with Datasphere

    • Connect multiple cloud and on-premise sources for unified analytics.

  • ⚡Cloud-Native Applications

    • Build extensions using SAP CAP, integrate with Fiori/UI5 apps, and leverage BTP services.

  • 🛠️ Automation & RPA

    • Automate repetitive processes and alerts for faster operational response.

  • 🚀Future-Ready ERP

    • Smooth path to S/4HANA Cloud or advanced SAP solutions under RISE with SAP.

Key Takeaways

  • 🚀Migration to SAP HANA Cloud is strategic, not just technical

  • 🛠️ Start with analytics or sandbox workloads first

  • 🖥️ Use SAP guides + Enable Now simulation to de-risk projects

  • 🌟Align migration with your RISE roadmap for long-term gains

entry.title: Re: BDCQ - Finance - Needs to be in sync with SAP Best Pr...
entry.content:
Hello @KP_2025 

Thank you for your question. Hope this still provides some support.

you are correct, in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the BDCQs sometimes show different descriptions for the same scope item compared to SAP Best Practices scope item documentation.

    • An example is: Scope Item 1QM is officially Advanced Financial Operations in the Best Practices Explorer. In the Finance BDCQ, the same scope item may still appear with the older description (Credit Evaluation and Management).

Here is why the mismatch tends to happen

  • BDCQs are maintained in Central Business Configuration. However, the scope item descriptions in Central Business Configuration may lag behind updates in the Best Practices Explorer.
  • The technical scope item ID (e.g. 1QM) is always the reliable reference, even if the wording differs.

Here is what I recommend

  • Always rely on the scope item ID (e.g. 1QM), not only the text description, when mapping BDCQ to Best Practices.
  • If the mismatch causes confusion whilst carrying out your project work, SAP recommends raising a support incident under component XX-S4C-OPR so that the CBC team can synchronize the descriptions with the latest Best Practice content.

The following references will provide further details:

Central Business Configuration – Business Driven Configuration Questionnaires

SAP Best Practices Explorer – Scope Items

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Down payments for Non-Trade Supplier are not applicab...
entry.content:
Hello @mbanggo 

This behaviour is expected in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public. The Manage Down Payment Request app Only Supports suppliers connected to trade payables' reconciliation accounts.

Non-trade suppliers, such as those linked to other liabilities, are excluded. Consequently, you cannot create down payment requests for them in the standard app.

Possible Workarounds

Manual posting, Use the Post Outgoing Payments (F1612) or Post General Journal Entries (F0718) app to generate the down payment directly and later offset it against the final payment invoice.

Supplier Invoice Request. Alternatively, you can start the payment manually, although this is not a genuine down payment request.

Extension approach: If down payments for Non-Trade suppliers occur frequently, you can consider a custom RAP app or workflow in SAP BTP or In-App Extensibility to replicate the request logic.

Process review. Some customers handle this by reclassifying certain suppliers under trade reconciliation accounts or by using a dummy PO to align with standard functionality.

KBA 3226814 – Restrictions in Manage Down Payment Requests

Down payments through the Manage Down Payment Request app are available only for Trade Suppliers. For Non-Trade Suppliers, you must use manual postings or develop an extension if this is a recurring need.

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Purchase Order Number Prefixing
entry.content:
Hello @MikaelaWard 

In the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, you can differentiate purchase order numbers by assigning distinct number range intervals to various PO document types. This is the standard approach for distinguishing between Stock, Non-Stock, and Service POs.

Configuring instructions

Define Number Ranges for Purchasing Documents

    • Create new number range intervals according to your business needs: 45xxxxxx for Services, 46xxxxxx for Non-Stock

Assign Number Ranges to Document Types

  • Assign each interval to a PO document type. If needed, create custom PO document types for Stock, Non-Stock, Service and link them to their own number ranges.

Notes / Special cases

This approach works for operational purchase orders.F2872 App

Alphabetic number ranges are only relevant for Central Purchase Orders F3292 App(Central Procurement scenario. See KBA 3596398 a for details, though these are not required for standard Pos

You cannot filter number ranges directly by PO created via MRP vs. manually; instead, the differentiation should be based on the PO document type. Assigning unique number ranges to different document types enables you to clearly distinguish between them.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Custom button calling a custom screen
entry.content:
Hello @mollopes 

Yes, it’s possible, but with RAP and OData V4, you won’t create a completely new screen the way we did in old dynpros.

In Fiori Elements, you typically address this in three ways, depending on how different that second screen truly needs to be.

Recommended bound action with parameters for better results.

    • You specify an action in your RAP behaviour by providing input parameters.
    • Fiori Elements makes it really easy by automatically showing a button and a parameter dialogue whenever the user clicks on it.
    • The user fills in additional fields, and you process them in your RAP handler.
    • This provides a pop-up screen without the need to build a new UI.

Navigation to another page or app

  • If you need a separate page, you can use intent-based navigation between two Fiori Elements apps or to a freestyle app.
  • You pass the current entity key as context, so the second app loads the same data plus extra fields.

Custom pop-up through controller extension

    • Add a custom action on the Object Page and open a UI5 dialogue with your own layout.
    • Within that dialogue, you can gather additional input and then manually invoke your RAP action.
    • Useful if you want more control over the UI than the standard action-parameter dialogue.

In the S/4HANA Public Cloud, you can’t create custom database screens or dynpros, so these patterns are the supported approach. For your use case, the same data, plus new fields and process option 1, is the simplest one, with a single button, a single dialogue, and all in line with standards.

Refer to below SAP useful documentation

ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model

SAP Help –ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model

SAP Help – Late Numbering in RAP

SAP Help-ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model

Let me know if you need further information

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Issue with BAPI_RESERVATION_CREATE1 – Reservation Not...
entry.content:
Hello @taher123 

Thank you for the information. Since you are using S/4HANA Public Cloud

MB23 isn’t available on Public Cloud. Use the Fiori apps, such as Manage Material Reservations (F7279), to create or view reservations.

BAPI_RESERVATION_CREATE1 is not a released API in Public Cloud (ABAP Cloud). Even if it returns success, it is not supported, and the document will not appear in the standard Fiori apps.

Alternative supported options.

  1. UI: Create/check reservations in Manage Material Reservations and related display/change apps.
  2. Integration and automation: Utilise the publicly available API for reservations, provided by the SAP API Business Accelerator Hub (A2X OData/REST). Access it through your extension (RAP/BTP Cloud SDK).)
  3. Auth check: Confirm your user has access to the Inventory Management business catalogues that include the reservation apps.

If you share the API you plan to call, I can provide a basic example payload, endpoint, and Cloud SDK snippet along with the exact Fiori app IDs.

With kind regards
Chuma

entry.title: SAP GRC for HANA 2026-Unified Successor for SAP Access Control 12.0, SAP Process Control 12 & More!
entry.content:
SAP GRC for HANA 2026 - Successor to SAP Access Control 12.0, SAP Process Control 12.0 and SAP Risk Management 12.0

As SAP Access Control 12.0, SAP Process Control 12.0 and SAP Risk Management 12.0 reach their End of Mainstream Maintenance on December 31st, 2027 &  Organizations accelerate their digital transformation with SAP S/4HANA- Governance, Risk and compliance (GRC) must evolve in parallel. To support this journey, SAP is introducing the next generation of its GRC solution: SAP GRC for HANA 2026.

This release marks a significant milestone, aligning SAP's GRC capabilities with the performance, scalability, and innovation of the SAP HANA platform. Designed natively for S/4HANA environments, GRC for HANA 2026 empowers businesses to manage risk, enforce compliance, and ensure access security with greater efficiency and intelligence.

What’s New in SAP GRC for HANA 2026:

SAP GRC for HANA 2026 builds on the proven foundation of GRC 12 while introducing new enhancements designed for modern enterprises:

SAP Fiori 3 User Experience: A modernized, intuitive user interface offers a consistent and streamlined experience across GRC modules, increasing user adoption and simplifying daily operations.

HANA-Native Performance: Leverages SAP HANA’s in-memory capabilities to enable faster data processing, real-time analytics, and scalable performance across large enterprise landscapes.

Enhanced Integration : Improved connectivity with cloud services, hybrid systems, and SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), enabling end-to-end risk visibility and control across environments.

AI-Driven Insights : Initial capabilities in machine learning and automation are being introduced to assist with access pattern analysis, risk identification, and anomaly detection.

Future-Ready Architecture: Built to support S/4HANA 2025 and beyond, with a roadmap aligned to SAP’s long-term strategy, ensuring your GRC investment is secure for the next decade.

Core Modules Supported: SAP GRC for HANA 2026 continues to support the full suite of core GRC modules, now optimized for the new platform:

Access Control – Manage user access, enforce SoD policies, and streamline provisioning with enhanced performance and usability.

Process Control – Automate control testing, monitor compliance in real-time, and gain greater transparency into internal controls.

Risk Management – Identify, assess, and respond to risks across the enterprise with improved analytics and integration.

Deployment and Compatibility- SAP GRC for HANA 2026 is designed to integrate seamlessly into both on-premise and cloud-centric S/4HANA landscapes. Whether you are migrating from GRC 12 or planning a greenfield implementation, the platform supports flexible deployment models to meet your organizational needs.

Key Outliners for the Upgrade Planning:

  • Modern, intuitive UX for business users and compliance teams
  • Faster risk and control analysis with real-time processing
  • Future-proof compliance aligned with SAP’s product roadmap
  • Scalable architecture for complex enterprise environments
  • Enhanced support for hybrid and cloud-first operations

As digital ecosystems grow more complex, organizations need a GRC platform that keeps pace. SAP GRC for HANA 2026 offers a robust, intelligent, and scalable solution for the next generation of compliance and risk management.

If you are a SAP MaxAttention, ActiveAttention Customer- please contact your Technical Quality Manager else the appropriate SAP Representative can be contacted.

SAP Americas Premium Engagements & Advisory (PE&A) Lead: Sam Minocha

entry.title: Re: No pg_hba.conf entry for host in SAP CF PostgreSQL Hy...
entry.content:
hello,
 I also faced the same error in NestJS and TypeORM  with postgres of BTP 
 and this is my solution 

 

@Module({})
export class DatabaseModuleBTP {
  static async forRoot(): Promise<DynamicModule> {
    const creds = JSON.parse(process.env.VCAP_SERVICES || '{}')["postgresql-db"][0].credentials;
    await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, 1000));
    return {
      module: DatabaseModuleBTP,
      imports: [
        TypeOrmModule.forRoot({
          type: 'postgres',
          host: creds.hostname,
          port: Number(creds.port),
          username: creds.username,
          password: creds.password,
          database: creds.dbname,
          ssl: {
            rejectUnauthorized: true,
            ca: creds.sslrootcert.replace(/\\n/g, '\n'),
            cert: creds.sslcert.replace(/\\n/g, '\n'),
          },

          entities: [__dirname + '/../**/*.entity{.ts,.js}'],
          synchronize: true,
          logging: ['query', 'error', 'log', 'warn', 'info'],
          autoLoadEntities: true,
        }),
      ],
    };
  }
}

entry.title: Re: BTP NodeJS Express API with PostgreSQL Database Conne...
entry.content:
I got the solution of NestJS and TypeORM BTP postgres

import { DynamicModule, Module } from '@nestjs/common';
import { TypeOrmModule } from '@nestjs/typeorm';

@Module({})
export class DatabaseModuleBTP {
  static async forRoot(): Promise<DynamicModule> {
    const creds = JSON.parse(process.env.VCAP_SERVICES || '{}')["postgresql-db"][0].credentials;
    await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, 1000));
    return {
      module: DatabaseModuleBTP,
      imports: [
        TypeOrmModule.forRoot({
          type: 'postgres',
          host: creds.hostname,
          port: Number(creds.port),
          username: creds.username,
          password: creds.password,
          database: creds.dbname,
          ssl: {
            rejectUnauthorized: true,
            ca: creds.sslrootcert.replace(/\\n/g, '\n'),
            cert: creds.sslcert.replace(/\\n/g, '\n'),
          },

          entities: [__dirname + '/../**/*.entity{.ts,.js}'],
          synchronize: true,
          logging: ['query', 'error', 'log', 'warn', 'info'],
          autoLoadEntities: true,
        }),
      ],
    };
  }
}​

entry.title: Commerce Automation - MIRO Invoice to SAP Business network
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

Could someone please confirm, in Ariba Commerce Automation, do we have a scenario where we will be able to send the MIRO Invoice to SAP Business Network?

Per our understanding of the Standard Commerce Automation scenarios. When we send a PO to SAP Business network from S/4HANA Private Cloud ERP or SAP ECC. Supplier can submit the invoice from Network and that will create the Invoice in S/4 Automatically, this is standard and working perfectly fine for us. In this case, if the supplier submits a Paper invoice to AP team, can they create invoice through MIRO T.Code in SAP and send the invoice to SAP business network? Can some please confirm if this channel is available by standard?

The other channel for sending invoice from SAP to SAP Business network what we have seen is through the ERS (Evaluated Receipt Settlement), by this channel, once the PO is created with the ERS flag at the line-item level, the invoice will be generated in SAP through the MRRL T.Code and these invoices will have the ERS output type which will then be sent to Network. So our question is, to send invoices from SAP to SAP Business network, is this the only channel, can we not send the invoices from SAP to Business Network via the MIRO at all? 

Thanks,
Velu

#SAPS/4HANA

entry.title: Re: SAP RAP Events local Consumption
entry.content:
Hello @AshishPandey 

Thanks for the details. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (ABAP environment), RAP business object events, such as R_PurchaseOrderTP → Created, are triggered at commit. If your event binding is set to queued/AT_COMMIT delivery, the handler executes asynchronously after the commit. During debugging, you typically wait at that point, which can make it seem as though the event only functions in debug mode.

Here’s a quick way to check it

Event Binding (ADT)

  • Open the Event Binding of R_PurchaseOrderTP.
  • For testing, set Delivery to IMMEDIATE and activate it. If it fires instantly, the previous behaviour was simply due to async timing.

Binding & Filters

  • Consumer type = Local Handler; Event = Created for R_PurchaseOrderTP.
  • Make sure no filter excludes your test data.

Draft vs. Active save

  • Fiori Purchase Order creation is draft based. The Created event triggers upon activation or final save, like Order, not while still in draft.

Handler class

  • Class is active and ABAP Cloud–compliant.
  • Implements the RAP event handler interface and method signature accurately, for instance:

CLASS zcl_po_evthdlr DEFINITION PUBLIC FINAL CREATE PUBLIC.

  PUBLIC SECTION.

    INTERFACES if_abap_behavior_event_handler.

    METHODS on_created FOR EVENTS created OF r_purchaseordertp

      IMPORTING keys.

ENDCLASS.

If you keep AT_COMMIT

  • Asynchronous delivery uses bgRFC (background Remote Function Call), which is managed in the Public Cloud. Wait a few seconds and check your application logs, such as the BAL application log, to verify it has been executed.

Do you need to run any extra checks on the program?
No. There’s nothing to schedule beyond activating the Event Binding. With IMMEDIATE, the handler runs in the same Logical Unit of Work; with AT_COMMIT, it’s processed automatically.

Develop Event-Based Integration-SAP Help 

ABAP Keyword Doc – METHODS … FOR ENTITY EVENT (handler signature for RAP events) 

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Functional area derivation using custom logic in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Functional areas in SAP S/4HANA Cloud are organizational units used for classifying expenses by their nature rather than by operational or geographical divisions. They serve as a key component in cost-of-sales accounting and enable businesses to prepare segmental financial statements for compliance and decision-making purposes. The derivation of functional areas is determined based on the sequence as explained here. In this short blog post, I would like to cover a practical example of how the functional area derivation works using a custom logic substitution rule, which is the last sequence step of the derivation logic. In this demo example, the use case is that the derivation should take place only for the company code 0800, and the default functional area will be substituted by a target functional area which is entered in a custom field of a professional services customer project. The prerequisite is creating and enabling the custom field YY1_Functional_Area_WP_cpd  in the business context "Work Package".

Step 1:

Create a custom logic implementation for the Extension Point FIN_CODING_BLOCK_SUBSTITUTION

Add the following code: in this example, if the Company Code 0800 is used, the custom logic will substitute the default functional area with the functional area entered by the user into the custom field.

* Note: please always copy the values from input to output first before

* any substitutions, otherwise, the initial values from the output will

* be used for substitutions!!

    MOVE-CORRESPONDING codingblockitem TO codingblockitemout.

 

DATA lv_project_target_fa type STRING.

*Only valid for customer projects, as the custom field is created in this context

IF codingblockitem-companycode = '0800'.

    SELECT YY1_Functional_Area_WP_cpd FROM I_WORKPACKAGE

    INTO @LV_project_target_fa

    WHERE WORKPACKAGE = @codingblockitem-wbselementexternalid.

    ENDSELECT.

    "If the custom field value if empty, no substitution

    If  lv_project_target_fa IS INITIAL.

        EXIT.

    ELSE.

        codingblockitemout-functionalarea = lv_project_target_fa.

        substitutiondone = abap_true.

    ENDIF.

ENDIF.

Next, create the substitution rule for this custom logic to be executed. In the “Manage Substitution/Validation Rules – Journal Entries” app, create a new rule for the business context Coding Block as follows:

 

The precondition determines in which cases the substitution rule will be triggered – in our demo use case, we want the rule to trigger only when the source functional area is equal to 'YB25'. The substitution rule itself simply maps the target field value to the value of the source field functional area (which will be set to a new value during the runtime of the custom logic). So essentially, if the customer project custom field has a target functional area 'YB24' maintained, the default functional area YB25 will be replaced by 'YB24'.

Once this is done, we can conduct a quick test to validate the result. The default functional area determined is YB25, and for our test project XDT0031, the custom field has been maintained with YB24 as the target functional area. After completing a test time booking for the project, the derivation result can be successfully validated in the "Display Line Items in General Ledger" app:

entry.title: Re: Link between customer details and material
entry.content:
SELECT
FROM vbak AS sh "Sales Document: Header Data
INNER JOIN vbap AS si "Sales Document: Item Data
ON sh~vbeln = si~vbeln
INNER JOIN mara AS mat "General Material Data
ON si~matnr = mat~matnr
INNER JOIN knvv AS custsalesorg "Customer Master Sales Data
ON sh~vkorg = custsalesorg~vkorg AND
sh~vtweg = custsalesorg~vtweg AND
sh~spart = custsalesorg~spart AND
sh~kunnr = custsalesorg~kunnr
FIELDS    sh~vbeln AS sales_order,
 mat~matnr AS material ,
    custsalesorg~kunnr AS customer,
     custsalesorg~vkorg AS salesorg,
       custsalesorg~vtweg AS distchannel,
         custsalesorg~spart AS division
          INTO TABLE @DATA(l_i_itab)
           UP TO 10 ROWS.
IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
ENDIF.

Aniketh B R

entry.title: Re: BRF+
entry.content:
NW ABAP Business Rule Framework (BRFplus)  is a rule engine and framework, that allows you to define, manage, and execute business rules separately from application code.

Instead of hardcoding business logic inside ABAP programs, BRF+ provides a declarative, model-driven approach to implement and maintain rules, making business processes more flexible and easier to adapt to changes.

Key Features of SAP BRF+:

  • Centralized Rule Management
    Rules are stored in a central repository, allowing reuse across multiple applications.

  • Graphical & User-Friendly Interface
    Business users and functional consultants (not only developers) can model rules using a browser-based UI (decision tables, decision trees, formulas, expressions, etc.).

  • Some of the expressions from which rules can be derived are :

    • Decision tables ( Similar to Excel tables for conditions and results)

    • Formulas (mathematical or logical expressions)

    • Decision trees (Hierarchial value derivation based on boolean expression result true or false) 

    • Case statements (Similar to abap case staments, alternative for an else-if ladder )

  • Integration with ABAP Applications
    Rules can be called from ABAP code via generated function modules.
    Example: VAT calculation, eligibility checks, or workflow decisions.

  • Transportable & Versionable
    Rules can be moved between SAP systems (Dev ->QA ->Preprod-> Prod) like standard customizing. Versions help track changes.

  • Separation of Concerns
    IT builds the framework; business experts manage the rules. This speeds up adaptation to new regulations or policies.

    Example Use Cases:

    • Tax determination (e.g., in SAP Tax and Revenue Management)

    • Credit checks in financial transactions

    • Claim eligibility in insurance

    • Workflow approvals based on configurable rules

    • Pricing, discounts, and surcharges in sales. 



    Inorder to create a simple BRF+ application from scratch please refer blog bost below :  


    Create a Simple Business Rule Framwork Plus application from scratch  


    Regards, 

    Aniketh B R

entry.title: Re: tables in BRF plus
entry.content:
For fetching name of any BRF+ object query the table : FDT_ADMN_0000

with OBJECT_TYPE field being : 
AP for Application
CA for Catalog
DO for Data Object
EX for Expression
FI for Filter
FU for Function
RS for Ruleset

For decision table use OBJECT_TYPE = EX since Decision table is also an expression. 


Regards, 

Aniketh B R

entry.title: Effective Axios Error Logging for Robust SAP Integrations
entry.content:
Comparing Error Responses: Which One Aids Debugging Better?

Suppose we have executed an HTTP request using CAP and it fails. Below are two logged error responses:

1st Scenario:

2nd Scenario:


It’s immediately clear which version is easier to debug and helps us quickly identify the reason for the failure.

When building SAP extensions or integrations, developers often rely on Axios for handling HTTP requests. While Axios simplifies API communication, error handling can quickly become a challenge—especially when debugging complex integration scenarios.

In many projects, errors are either logged with too little detail (just a generic message) or with too much raw data, making debugging time-consuming. To improve maintainability and speed up root cause analysis, we need a structured error logging mechanism.

Why Structured Error Logging Matters

In enterprise scenarios like SAP SuccessFactors or SAP BTP service integrations, requests often involve multiple systems. Without detailed error insights, you might only see:

Error: Request failed with status code 400

 But what you really need is:

  • Which endpoint failed?

  • What payload was sent?

  • What was the response from the server?

  • Was there any custom error code attached?

This is where a structured error handling approach becomes invaluable.

Implementation: A Structured Axios Error Logger

Here’s a reusable utility function you can plug into your Node.js / TypeScript projects:

public getAxiosErrorObject(error: any) {
  if (error.isAxiosError) {
    const errorObj = {
      message: error.message || 'An error occurred during the request.',
      code: error.code || 'UNKNOWN',
      status: error.response ? error.response.status : 'No Status',
      statusText: error.response ? error.response.statusText : 'No Status Text',
      requestData: error.config ? error.config.data : 'No Request Data',
      requestMethod: error.config ? error.config.method : 'No Request Method',
      requestUrl: error.config ? error.config.url : 'No Request URL',
      responseData: error.response ? error.response.data : 'No Response Data'
    };
    return errorObj;
  }
  return {
    message: error.message || 'An unknown error occurred',
    stack: error.stack || 'No Stack Trace'
  };
}

 

How It Works

  • Checks if it’s an Axios error
    Axios sets error.isAxiosError = true. This allows us to distinguish between HTTP request errors and other runtime issues.

  • Captures request details
    The request URL, method, and payload are logged, which is crucial for reproducing and debugging issues.

  • Captures response details
    If the server responded, we extract the status code, status text, and response body.

  • Fallback for non-Axios errors
    In cases where the error didn’t come from Axios (e.g., runtime exceptions), we still log a meaningful message and stack trace.

Example Usage

try {
  const response = await axios.post('/api/employees', { name: 'Sahil M' });
  console.log(response.data);
} catch (error) {
  const structuredError = this.getAxiosErrorObject(error);
  console.error('API Error:', structuredError);
}

Example Output  

{
  "message": "Request failed with status code 400",
  "code": "ERR_BAD_REQUEST",
  "status": 400,
  "statusText": "Bad Request",
  "requestData": "{\"name\":\"Sahil M\"}",
  "requestMethod": "post",
  "requestUrl": "/api/employees",
  "responseData": {
    "error": "Invalid employee data"
  }
}

Best Practices

  1. Avoid logging sensitive data
    When logging request payloads, ensure no confidential fields (e.g., passwords, tokens) are exposed.

  2. Integrate with monitoring tools
    Forward structured error logs to tools like SAP Cloud Logging for central monitoring.

  3. Normalize error structure
    Use this function as a single source of truth for error logging across your project, ensuring consistent logs.

  4. Enhance with correlation IDs
    In SAP integrations, add transaction or correlation IDs to quickly trace requests across systems.

Hi @deepakmk1996 ,

This can be acheived through BRF+, Please follow the steps given below: 

1. Navigate to transaction USMD_RULE (Definition of rules for validations and derivations)

2. Enter the data model, since here its Business partner requirement, enter BP

3. Under FMDM_MODEL_BP application expand function CHECK_ENTITY

4.  Create a function with naming convention CHECK_<Entity_Name> (Entity name you can get to know using transaction MDGIMG)

5. Add context data object ( select structure based on the entity ) 

6. Create a Ruleset for the function 

7. Define you validation rule, additionally you can create an action log message and assign to result if you want to perform log message action in the MDG UI screen if validation fails thereby informing user via warning or error message.

entry.title: Re: BAPI to read table CRMS4D_EXT_REF in SAP S4 HANA
entry.content:
Hello @Gayatri_Bagde 

Thanks for the detailed notes. I reviewed your setup, and the 403 responses are expected given how each API is authenticated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition.

Why do two work while the others do not?

  • Some APIs are intended for end users and support SAML bearer (principal propagation). Examples include Business Partner, Sales Order, and Product. These require the appropriate business roles and, importantly, maintained restrictions such as Sales Organisation, Plant, and Storage Location. When restrictions are set to 'No Access', metadata is loaded, but data reads return a 403 error.
  • Other APIs are technical or system-focused and do not accept SAML bearer tokens. Examples in your case include Material Stock and Sales Organisation. These must be accessed using a Communication User via a Communication Arrangement with Basic authentication or a client certificate. Assigning more roles to a human user will not alter this behaviour.

What needs to be changed

Keep SAML bearer for end-user APIs

    • Keep using your SAML destination for Business Partner, Sales Order, and Product.
    • In Manage Business Roles, open the roles you've assigned and configure Restrictions. Set Read and Value Help to either Restricted or Unrestricted, then specify the allowed values for Sales Org, Plant, and Storage Location.
    • If your trust uses email as the NameID, add this to the BTP destination:
      nameIdFormat = urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:1.1:nameid-format:emailAddress.

Change the technical APIs to a Communication User.

    • For Material Stock and Sales Organisation, create a Communication User, Communication System, and Communication Arrangement for each API. communication scenario in S/4HANA Cloud.
    • Create a separate destination in BTP with Authentication = BasicAuthentication (or client certificate) that points to the API base URL.
    • Use this Basic or x509 destination exclusively for specific APIs in your UI5 app.

Example destination (Basic)

Name = S4C_MaterialStock_Basic

Type = HTTP

URL  = https://<your-s4c-host>/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV/

Authentication = BasicAuthentication

User = <COMM_USER>

Password = <********>

Quick review of your list

  • Business Partner, Sales Order, Product: SAML bearer is acceptable once role restrictions are applied.
  • Material Stock, Sales Organisation: call with a Communication User via a Basic or x509 destination.

If you'd like, I can map an entire API end-to-end, providing you with a template that includes the communication scenario to activate, the specific role restrictions to maintain, and the destination properties to use in BTP.

Material Stock Integration (SAP_COM_0164)-SAP Help

3445942 - UI Development in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Frequently Asked Questions

With kind regards
Chuma

entry.title: Re: Clean core in PP-DS and AATP in S/4HANA PCE: how much...
entry.content:
Hello @goedele_derveaux 

Great question. Here’s a clear plan that aligns with the clean core approach in S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition (PCE), and ensures you remain upgrade-safe.

Aim for ABAP Cloud and released APIs/BAdIs first, keeping anything traditional to a minimum. Use the three-tier extensibility model: Tier 1 is on-stack released, Tier 2 is wrappers/side-by-side, and Tier 3 is only used when no released alternative exists. Explaining Extensibility Model Best Practices-SAP Learning  and Clean core extensibility of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition with ABAP Cloud

aATP: Prefer standard capabilities (PAL, BOP, ABC, Supply Protection). When you need to influence results, use released aATP BAdIs such as the ABC substitution BAdIs. If the gap exceeds the released points, compare the logic side by side and call it accordingly APIs. SAP Help Portal-Advanced Available-to-Promise (aATP)

PP-DS: Start with standard planning procedures and heuristics. Only extend via released PP-DS BAdIs when needed; avoid bespoke heuristics unless there is no standard equivalent. SAP Help Portal

How to remediate the ~140 custom objects

Triage each object and assign a landing zone: Tier 1 (released BAdI/API), Tier 2 (ABAP Cloud wrapper or BTP service), Tier 3 (last resort). Ensure ABAP Cloud readiness with ATC. SAP Learning

Replace with standard where possible: aATP features and PP-DS procedures first, then add released BAdIs only for true gaps. SAP Help Portal/Extensibility in aATP

Isolate what remains: small, documented Tier 3, with a deprecation plan. Use side-by-side for heavy algorithms.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Change Management in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
It’s important not to confuse Change Request Management (ChaRM) in SAP ALM or Solution Manager with Organizational Change Management (OCM). While ChaRM focuses on managing technical and system configuration changes, OCM addresses the human side of change—communication, adoption, and cultural alignment. 
In an S/4 migration project, both dimensions must work together: registering and controlling change requests is essential, but so is communicating them effectively to ensure user adoption and business continuity.

entry.title: SAP CPQ - Improve Productivity for Developer Extensions for IronPython Debugging
entry.content:
Today SAP CPQ it needs developers to do scripting with strong understanding of Ironpython, Developers must be familiar not only with IronPython syntax but also with the CPQ-specific libraries and APIs to effectively meet complex customer requirements.  
Testing and validating these scripts against business scenarios can be time-consuming and error-prone, especially when switching between tabs or tools to debug and refine logic. This often slows down delivery and increases cognitive load for developers working on tight timelines.

That’s exactly where this Chrome extension comes in and That’s why I built a tailored specifically for helping my productivity s—a tool designed to streamline IronPython testing and debugging, right from within the CPQ Quote interface. Watch out short demo below.

Why CPQ Developers Will Love This when Offically available in future.

SAP CPQ is a fast-growing product in the market, and with that growth comes increasing demand for development speed, precision, and productivity. CPQ Developers and Modellers are often deeply involved in customer projects, spending significant time in scripting and testing IronPython logic.

This Chrome extension is designed to support their work directly within the CPQ Quote interface, helping them implement solutions faster, debug more efficiently, and stay focused without switching tabs or tools. It’s a smarter way to work—guided, streamlined, and AI-enhanced.

What Does It Do?

This extension is a developer’s sidekick, offering:

  • ✅ Inline IronPython Testing: Run and debug scripts directly in the CPQ Quote page—no need to open another tab.
  • ✅ Syntax Correction with AI: Choose from integrated AI models that auto-correct and optimize your IronPython code.
  • ✅ Context-Aware Suggestions: Get real-time guidance based on the current quote context, reducing trial-and-error.
  • ✅ Distraction-Free Workflow: Stay focused with a seamless, embedded experience—no switching between tools.

Built for Efficiency

By embedding this tool directly into the CPQ UI, this will eliminate the friction of context switching. Developers can:

  • Instantly validate logic
  • Test edge cases on the fly
  • Learn from AI-powered suggestions
  • Improve code quality and reduce bugs

Why It Matters

This extension isn’t just a convenience—it’s a productivity multiplier. It empowers developers to:

  • Deliver faster
  • Reduce errors
  • Learn and adapt with AI
  • Stay in the flow

Short Demo

Final Thoughts

This Chrome extension is more than a tool—it’s a CPQ developer companion that helps you code smarter, debug faster, and stay focused. Whether you're a seasoned CPQ expert or just getting started, this extension will elevate your workflow.

Disclaimer

This Chrome extension is purely built based on my own personal experience in developing Chrome extensions, deep knowledge of JavaScript, Ironpython, AI/RAG - LLM specifically for CPQ libraries and most important of experience in CPQ implementation. It is not an official SAP CPQ product extension and is not available for public use.

If you’re interested in seeing similar functionality in the official SAP CPQ product, I encourage you to raise a request via the SAP CPQ Customer Influence Portal.

entry.title: Unlocking MDF Power: A Practical User Case in SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Today, I would like to share a custom MDF (Metadata Framework) use case that addresses a complex requirement related to Finance Cost Internal Control. While this specific requirement may not be applicable across all industries, the case demonstrates:

  • The capabilities of no-code MDF,

  • Its limitations and common workarounds,

  • A structured step-by-step problem-solving approach to achieve business outcomes through custom MDF design.

Business Requirement

Customer A has a strict internal cost control policy. The expense limit amount an employee can approve for direct reports (without Finance involvement) depends on Job Grade, Business Unit, and Expense Type, a workflow is needed if the data is needed to be updated based on if the limit guidance is exceeded.

Key UI Requirements

  1. A user-friendly form for employees to review costs and submit new applications with workflow.

  2. Expense limit guidelines and manager’s limit must be displayed for reference:

    • Expense guideline = based on Job Grade, Business Unit, and Expense Type.

    • Manager’s limit = retrieved from manager’s corresponding expense record.

    • Alerts:

      • Soft alert if Employee Limit > Guideline.

      • Error alert if Employee Limit > Manager Limit.

      • Error Alert if Employee select the item which is not available in manager's form.

  3. Expense amounts must be converted based on the source currency (multi-currency setup across business units).

  4. A unique record must exist per Business Unit and Expense Type.

  5. When viewing others’ expense data:

    • Only the latest record should be visible.

    • Some fields (e.g., attachments) must be hidden.

Workflow Requirements

  1. If Employee Limit <= Guideline and Employee Limit <= Manager Limit → Manager approval only.

  2. If Employee Limit > Guideline in any item → Manager + Finance Business Partner approval required.

  3. Records approved by Finance should not be flagged again as exceeding the guideline in the next application process.

  4. Finance approvers vary by applicant’s department.

  5. Both employees and managers (on behalf of direct reports) must be able to submit requests.

Requirement Analysis

RequirementCategoryReasoningHow to AchieveDifficulty (1–5)
User-friendly form & workflowMDF FormMultiple expense types, history & audit requiredEffective-dated parent-child MDF entity + MDF version history3
Unique record per BU + Expense TypeMDF FormPrevent duplicatesExternalCode = String Type + onSave rule to auto-generate key (UserID+BU+Type)4
Expense guideline lookupBusiness RuleBased on Job Grade, BU, Expense TypeLookup table + auto-populate via rule2
Manager’s limitBusiness RuleDerived from manager’s recordLookup manager’s expense MDF form + auto-populate4
Currency conversionBusiness RuleMultinational setupLookup standard exchange rate table in SF3
Alerts for inappropriate limitsBusiness RulePrevent policy breachWarning & Error rules (onChange + onSave)2
Workflow conditionsWorkflow + RulesApproval logic across multiple itemsWorkflow rules with “Where” criteria5
Exclude already approved itemsWorkflow + RulesFinance-approved items shouldn’t re-trigger approvalAdd flag + exclude via “Where” condition5
Finance approver per departmentWorkflow + Dynamic RoleApprover varies by departmentCreate standalone dynamic role group2
Permissions for visibilityRBP + Field PermissionsControl record & field accessTarget populations + No Access permissions3

Technical Solution Overview

Form Design

  • Parent-child MDF entity for expense form.

  • Effective dating for history tracking.

  • A user can only maintain a record per one Expense Type and Business Unit.

TableField NameField TypeEmployee PermissionNotes
Expense ApplicationApplicantuserreadAutomatically populated
Expense ApplicationGradepicklistreadAuto-populated from job info via business rule
Expense ApplicationBusiness UnitGOreadAuto-populated from job info via business rule
Expense ApplicationApplication Reasonstringwrite 
Expense ApplicationAttachmentattachmentNo Access 
Expense ItemExternal CodestringRead-Only Field in Objection DefinitionAuto-populated based on UserId, BU and Expense Type.
Expense ItemExpense TypepicklistwritePicklist is maintained by admin.
Expense ItemBusiness Unitstringread 
Expense ItemCurrencyGOreadSF have standard Currency MDF object.
Expense ItemExpense Limit (Guideline)numberRead-Only Field in Objection DefinitionAuto-populated Expense Limit(Guideline) trhough Lookup function based on Expense type, job grade and business unit. 
Expense ItemManager LimitnumberRead-Only Field in Objection DefinitionAuto-populated Line Manager’s limit trhough Lookup function.
Expense ItemEmployee LimitnumberWrite 
Expense ItemSpecial ApprovalpicklistRead-Only Field in UIFinance BP Maintain it as “Yes” for the records in which employee limit exceed the limit after it is approved

Business Rules

  1. Approval Workflow conditions: The condition section should evaluate every possible combination of scenarios.

  2. Auto-population of manager limit through Looking up MDF form 

  3. Currency conversion logic: The currency rate could vary per month according to the effective date)

  4. Alerts for expense type violations. Trigger error message if the selected item is not available in your manager's form.

  5. External Code Auto-Generation: For integration scenarios, always use String-type external codes with auto-generation onsave rule when fixed logic could be set up.

Limitations & Workarounds

  1. UI Layout for Parent-Child MDF

    • Grid layout not supported in Employee Profile for Parent-Child MDF.

    • Long scroll issue exists in Employee Profile if many child records exist, but grid form layout natively works in Manage Data.

  2. Pending Data Visibility

    • Pending records are not shown natively in Employee Profile.

    • However, they are visible in Manage Data with alerts an an expected even if only "view current" permission is given.

  3. Workflow Restriction

    • Workflows can only be attached at Parent Object level.

    • Requires complex conditions to evaluate all child records to trigger workflow. See KBA: 2839730 MDF Parent object triggering the wrong workflow based on the child record inserted

  4. Dynamic Role Limitation

    • Approvers cannot be directly derived from Department object.

    • Standalone dynamic roles must be created.

  5. Field Level Permission Gaps

    • Field-level permissions only respected in Parent Object, not Child. See KBA: 2303419 RBP Permission for MDF Composite Child Object does not respect Target Population for Field Level Overrides

  6. Read-Only Behavior Differences

     Manage Objection DefinitionBusiness Configuration UIFinal Behaviour
    "Special Approval" Field Attribute-Option1EditableRead-Onlyreadable in Employee Profile but editable in "Workflow Update"/"manage Data" portal.
    "Special Approval" Field Attribute-Option2Read-OnlyRead-OnlyReadable both in Employee Profile and "Workflow Update"/"manage Data" portal.

  7. MDF is userId-based (not personalExternalId).

    1. Sometimes it is not user-friendly when it is personal.

    2. Multiple Expense exist for concurrent employment.

Conclusion

This case highlights how SuccessFactors MDF can be extended to support complex Finance cost control policies. Despite its limitations, with the right design patterns and careful use of lookup tables, workflow rules, and permissions, MDF can achieve highly specific business requirements.

About the Author

I am an SAP SuccessFactors Consultant, passionate about HRIS technology and practical implementation design. I welcome discussions and knowledge sharing. Connect with me on LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/shilin-song-2742b6293/

entry.title: Re: PPF- Autopack
entry.content:
Hello @Dhilipkumar 

You can not implement a custom PPF action for auto-pack in Public Cloud.

PPF customising and custom action definitions are part of EWM on-prem/PCE. In Public Warehouse Management (Public Cloud), the supported method for auto-packing inbound deliveries is to use Packaging Specifications and the Auto Pack function in the Fiori apps. In other words, set up the packing rules; the system will execute them via the standard UI action, no custom PPF required (or possible.

What to do instead (works in Public Cloud)

Maintain Packaging Specifications for the products/vendor/conditions you need.

In Change Inbound Deliveries (F1706) → Packing Work Centre, select the unpacked items and use Auto Pack / Pack according to Packaging Specification. The system generates HUs according to your specifications. If you require lights-out automation, the Public Cloud pattern is to manage the process via standard applications, jobs, and packaging specifications, rather than adding custom PPF logic.

Why your approach hits a wall

PPF custom actions cannot be extended in Public Warehouse Management; this feature is exclusive to EWM in Private Edition/on-premises. Public Cloud instead offers built-in auto-pack buttons driven by your Packaging Specifications.

Useful SAP references, official sources, and the SAP community

SAP Help (Public Cloud): Automatic Packing in the Inbound Delivery (how to use the function in the Fiori apps. SAP Help Portal

What’s new (Public Cloud): Auto-pack button based on Packaging Specifications. SAP Community

If you share a sample material/vendor and the desired HU outcome, I can outline the precise Packaging Specification levels and condition keys you’ll need so that the delivered Auto Pack functions as intended.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Hi What is the difference between document routing no...
entry.content:
Hi @KeerthiCG,

 

The Document Routing Notification is an email alert sent to users when a performance form is routed to their Inbox. 

Document Routing Step Exit Notification is sent when a form step is completed. For this notification, you can select the recipient and the condition that will be sent.

1. Both email notifications can be triggered. The Document Routing notification will be sent to the form recipient. The Document Routing Step Exit Notification will be sent to the Recipient and will depend on the selection for this option, "Select Document Routing Notification option".

2. If the current step and the next step owner are the same person or role, the Document Routing Notification and Document Routing Step Exit Notification will not be sent.

3. Yes. These notifications are sent on the signature step.

4. No. These email notifications are not sent in the completed stage.

 

Please see our Admin Guide for more information: https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-performance-and-goals/implementing-and-managing-performance-management/email-notifications?q=Document+Routing+Step+Exit+Notification

 

Regards,

Michael

entry.title: UPDATE: SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud Availability via SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
After the announcement on July 1st regarding the availability of SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud (public option) via SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), the reaction was of great excitement and interest in learning more about the next steps especially about the tenant rewiring option to move existing tenants to SAP BDC. If you missed the announcement, you could read it here: Announcement: SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud - SAP Community

The objective of this blog is to share with you the latest information about the tenant rewiring and what it involves.

First, what does it mean for an SAP Datasphere or SAP Analytics Cloud to be rewired?

A tenant rewiring does not mean artefacts or data migration, it mainly refers to the consumption approach (from a commercial model perspective) of these services, and to the customer facing tool to manage the tenant lifecycles (via SAP for Me).  The tenant itself will remain the same, and the URL of the current tenants will not change either. In addition, there are no additional charges for rewiring an SAP Datasphere or SAP Analytics Cloud tenant to SAP BDC.

Second, how will the tenant rewiring work?

There are two paths for customers when it comes to how the tenant rewiring will work.

Customers may have started their consumption of SAP Datasphere or SAP Analytics Cloud (public option) via one of the following consumption models:

  • A subscription of the services where the tenants are provisioned and managed by SAP
  • A subscription of the services where the tenants are provisioned self-service by customers via the customers SAP BTP Global Accounts.

The tenant rewiring tool will support both models; however, the way the process is triggered will be different.

For the SAP-managed / provisioned tenants, the tenant rewiring will be initiated automatically as soon as you update your subscription with SAP (via your SAP account team) to move your subscription from the standalone product subscription to the SAP BDC subscription. This means that the tenant rewiring will be initiated as part of your subscription change request, and the tenant will automatically move to SAP BDC.

When you have a new subscription to SAP BDC, you will receive an email notification from SAP to log into your SAP for Me account. You will need to activate your BDC cockpit in your appropriate data center. If these steps are done prior to the tenant rewiring process, you will be able to see the rewired tenants in your BDC formation as soon as the process is completed.

NOTE: You must use the same hyperscaler and the same data center for your BDC cockpit as your current standalone subscription. The tenant rewiring tool does not migrate tenants between hyperscalers or data centers.

It is important to mention that the tenant will be available for your end users during the process and there is no tenant downtime required by the tenant rewiring tool.

For the tenants that are provisioned self-service via the customers SAP BTP Global Account, your admin will be able to initiate the tenant rewiring directly via the BTP Global Account, also self-service. The only pre-condition required is that a BDC subscription must pre-exist before triggering the tenant rewiring process to move the tenant to SAP BDC.

The steps are as follows:

  • BTP Admin goes in the BTP Global Account / BTP cockpit and updates the BTP Service instance related to the tenant
  • The request is received by SAP and the process is initiated to update the tenant and move it to BDC
  • Login to SAP for Me and, login to BDC, go to the resources tab where you will be able to find the rewired tenants under “bdc-rewired” resource group.
  • Once the rewiring is completed, the tenant will be visible in BDC

Overall, the tenants are preserved and now will be consumed via SAP BDC.

For more information and step-by-step, visit the tenant rewiring documentation.

SAP Analytics Cloud in this blog refers to the following:

  • SAP Analytics Cloud for business intelligence, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud for planning, standard edition, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud for planning, professional edition, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud, test tenant, public system option

With new and no prior knowledge of SAP I was little reluctant of what future holds. But as time passed and I got a clearer picture of my role (which was a functional consultant) i found mh job exciting and enjoyable as I was doing what I always wanted to do (to be in an IT field).

With now almost 2 years in the field with multiple certifications in Successfactors and accreditations along with an S4 Hana implementation project I have never been happier. I have worked on implementing IAS/IPS and then joule on our testing environment at our organisation and every day brings a new challenge and with a new challenge always a new opportunity to learn and get better.

entry.title: Re: Checking the JSON file log
entry.content:
Hi @ISoma 

Thank you for your question.

This depends on a the solution you use. Below are possible scenarios depending on the use case.

If you are using SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

In Public Cloud, there is no standard Fiori app that allows you to directly view raw JSON file logs from the Launchpad.

However, here is what you can do instead

  1. Using the Application Log App (F4879)
    • You can view logs of background jobs, OData API calls, and integration processes.
    • However, the log is structured text, not raw JSON.
  2. When using message Monitoring Apps (for integrations via Communication Arrangements)
    • Message Monitoring (Message Dashboard)
    • Application Interface Framework , Monitoring and Error Handling (AIF)
    • These allow you to see payloads (XML/JSON) for failed/successful messages.
  3. If you use SAP Cloud ALM or SAP Integration Suite
    • If the JSON is part of an integration flow, you can monitor and view payloads in Integration Suite à Monitor Message Processing.

If SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition is in use

In Private Cloud, you can view raw payloads including JSON directly in the system because you have access to:

  • Transaction SLG1 (Application Log) --> to view detailed logs including payloads if enabled by the application.
  • Transaction SXMB_MONI (PI/XI monitoring) --> for checking XML/JSON payloads in middleware.
  • Transaction /AIF/ERR (Application Interface Framework) --> to view and reprocess messages including raw JSON or XML content.
  • Custom ABAP development --> you could create a custom Fiori app or report that reads the JSON logs from database tables (if stored) and displays them in Launchpad.

Happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: 交货单超信贷了，传OA进行特批；想把标准APP：管理已记录的信用决策(manage documented...
entry.content:
你好 @michael_mx 

Machine Solution translation: 机器翻译

在SAP S/4HANA Cloud公共版中，标准应用程序“管理记录的信用决策”(F5340)会显示因信用风险暴露导致的被阻塞交货的详细信息（如信用风险暴露、风险等级、信用分段、付款行为等）。

若需将这些特定字段发送至外部OA审批工作流，可采用两种支持方案：

使用信用管理的已发布API

SAP提供API_CREDITMEMOITEM_PROCESS_SRV等API及信用管理API，用于暴露记录的信用决策数据。

可通过这些API提取红框标注字段（信用风险敞口、风险等级、被阻金额、责任人等），将其推送至OA系统。

基于业务事件的自定义扩展

当交付因信用检查被阻塞时，系统将触发业务事件。

您可在SAP BTP中订阅该事件，并通过已发布的CDS视图/API为其补充所需的信用决策详情。

增强后的数据负载可转发至OA系统进行审批。

在公有云环境中无法直接增强“管理记录信用阻塞”应用以“发送”这些字段。支持的方式是通过API + 事件处理实现。

希望这能解决您的问题。如有其他疑问，欢迎随时垂询。

此致
敬礼
克里斯
